title: <italic>Rasgrp1</italic> mutation increases naïve T-cell CD44 expression and drives mTOR-dependent accumulation of Helios<sup>+</sup> T cells and autoantibodies
abstract: Missense variants are a major source of human genetic variation. Here we analyze a new mouse missense variant, <italic>Rasgrp1</italic><sup>undefined</sup>, with an ENU-mutated EF hand in the Rasgrp1 Ras guanine nucleotide exchange factor. <italic>Rasgrp1</italic><sup>undefined</sup> mice exhibit anti-nuclear autoantibodies and gradually accumulate a CD44<sup>hi</sup> Helios<sup>+</sup> PD-1<sup>+</sup> CD4<sup>+</sup> T cell population that is dependent on B cells. Despite reduced Rasgrp1-Ras-ERK activation in vitro, thymocyte selection in <italic>Rasgrp1</italic><sup>undefined</sup> is mostly normal in vivo, although CD44 is overexpressed on naïve thymocytes and T cells in a T-cell-autonomous manner. We identify CD44 expression as a sensitive reporter of tonic mTOR-S6 kinase signaling through a novel mouse strain, <italic>chino</italic>, with a reduction-of-function mutation in <italic>Mtor</italic>. Elevated tonic mTOR-S6 signaling occurs in <italic>Rasgrp1</italic><sup>undefined</sup> naïve CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells. CD44 expression, CD4<sup>+</sup> T cell subset ratios and serum autoantibodies all returned to normal in <italic>Rasgrp1</italic><sup>undefined</sup><italic>Mtor</italic><sup>undefined</sup> double-mutant mice, demonstrating that increased mTOR activity is essential for the <italic>Rasgrp1</italic><sup>undefined</sup> T cell dysregulation.
